Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Building HSI Learning Resilience in the Face of Crisis

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration: With support from the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSI Program), this conference aims to understand the effects of the pandemic and its continuing impact on HSI studentsâ€™ learning. As the COVID-19 pandemic became confirmed in all 50 states in March 2020, there was an abrupt move to fully distance learning instruction and closing of college campuses, leading to many uncertainties for all institutions, including Hispanic-Serving Institutions. To combat this, the proposed conference will bring 100-150 participants into a 3-day virtual conference. All video and related materials for sharing will be archived in the conference web page post meeting for public access. In the current environment, the notions of experiential, place-based, collaborative, and community centered learning practices have been deeply challenged. Furthermore, these challenges are predicted to have a disproportionately large impact on underserved student populations who benefit the most from these innovative learning approaches (generally identified as first generation, Pell recipient, Latinx, African American, and Native American). As such, there is an urgent need to document what is happening and develop new solutions to improve outcomes. This conference will document the understanding of current practices to create resiliency with an emphasis on exploring new digital tools to enhance distance learning. <br/><br/>This project will primarily focus on (a) Mitigating the Digital Divide; (b) Lab, Design Projects, and Internships from a Distance; (c) Enhancing Mentoring using Distance learning Tools; (d) Digital Learning: What are HSI Faculty, Students, and Families of Students Saying?; (e) Use of Data Science to Inform Nextgen Learning Software; and (f) Quo vadis?, a forum to understand how the HSI community will plan to adapt digital tools discussed post conference. This conference will also enable participants to: 1) collaborate with other institutions during breakout sessions; (2) work through scenarios in tabletop drills with other HSIs; (3) gain access to recordings of the event to reinforce what was learned and view breakout sessions; and (4) build a community powered by new digital tools to develop new tools and prime ideas for future conferences, symposia, webinars, and workshops. Capacity using webinar tools will allow synchronous access to the conference to a wider audience interested in the conference topic. This conference will include administrators, faculty, students, and families of students to better disseminate ideas of digital learning tools. Attending this conference has the potential to improve the ability of HSIs to be resilient and to bounce-back now and in the future as faculty, students, and family will be more knowledgeable from shared knowledge acquired during the conference. <br/><br/>The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During November 2-4, 2020 the Building HSI Learning Resilience in the Face of Crisis saw 150 persons attending the 3-day conference. The four discussion sessions provided a venue for attendees and presenters to exchange ideas in an informal setting. The goals of the conference were to understand the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and its continuing impact on Hispanic Serving Institution student learning and enhance distance learning by understanding the current practices in order to create resiliency with an emphasis on exploring new digital tools. 

A count of 86 faculty and students presented a total of 13 panel sessions, 12 presented papers, 11 poster sessions, a workshop, and an opening plenary. Approximately 150 individuals attended. The conference schedule was organized into five major themes: Mitigating the Digital Divide, Lab, Design Projects, and Internships from a Distance, Enhancing Mentoring using Distance Learning, Digital Learning: What are HSI Faculty, Students, and Families of Students Saying?, Use of Data Science to Inform Nextgen Learning Software, and Quo Vadis? A Forum to Understand how the HSI Community will plan to Adapt Digital Tools. In addition, the third day of the conference featured four discussion sessions following the main conference themes, a panel discussion, and a closing plenary session.  Due to pandemic stay-at-home measures and the need to find a platform that would support interactive functionalities similar to in-person conferences, the conference platform contained virtual meeting rooms and a lobby patterned after in-person lecture halls. Attendees and presenters were able to sit at virtual tables and interact with other attendees. After-event survey respondents noted that they liked the “flexible format” and that the “ability to have small table conversations to network made it feel more like an in-person conference” to make “connections.” Conference sessions took place in two lecture halls containing tables for attendees to virtually meet and watch live streaming video of the presenters along with a conference staff moderator, and staff. Presentation slides were presented along with live video of presenters in an easy to use window that also offered the opportunity to interact with presenters via moderated chat.

 A survey administered to the conference attendees gave the following responses.  Over half of the respondents expressed positive views of the interactive conference platform, stating that the conference was “well-organized,” “awesome,” “amazing,” “useful,” “pretty cool,” and expressed gratitude for support from staff. Common themes among positive responses describing what worked well at the event included references to event session content, the conference platform, overall positive comments about the conference, no cost to attend, presentation practice sessions for presenters, and the staff support. Representative positive statements included “The panels were great, especially where there were 3-5 students and the less formal moderation,” “The flexible format,” and “I really appreciate that there were no fees involved to participate or present.” Answers to the question asking how the conference influenced attendees’ perception of learning during this time of crisis were positive and included many statements referring to the opportunity to learn best practices and strategies from presenters and other attendees. Comments of this type included statements such as “I learned several strategies and understood the challenges faced by many,” “I did gain some insights into methods to improve online classes,” “It provided different perspectives on this topic,” and “Hearing from others I learned about new ways to think and work.”

 A common theme present in responses to the conference’s influence on attendees’ perception of learning and favorite questions or experiences prompt included positive reception, perception of value, and relevance of the student presenters. Attendees were “impressed with the students,” valued the chance to hear ”directly from the students,” and rated “understanding the student perspectives” highly. Favorite moments and takeaways responses were entirely positive and clustered around the topics of conference presenters and staff, conference session content, student presenters, and miscellaneous positive statements about the conference. Survey responses indicated that attendees felt the conference session content was “informative,” allowed attendees to “gain insights into methods to improve online classes,” and left attendees feeling “energized.” Survey respondents were given an opportunity to include final feedback and suggestions at the end of the survey. Most responses were positive and expressed positive overall feedback about the conference and expressed gratitude. Several responses expressed support for a future national conference in the next year to continue the “overall great experience,” “great conference,” “meaningful experiences,” and “diversity of topics.”
